content.description:
Clamber up into the ledge on the left side of Air Voyage wall, start up blocky jugs and cracks trending right. Pumpy climbing leads to an intermediate anchor in a small recess (5.10). Now climb leftwards to a horn jug, place your gear and commit to a tough yet brief thin crack (face holds). Easily finish up and further left at chains. Amazing climb with great sequences separated by jovial rests. Center Air Voyage wall Single rack to #3 C4 with small selection of stoppers...don't forget your nuts too
70m will get you to the ground from upper anchors.

Start as for Mr Rogers and Mr Plod but take a hard right at the third bolt attacking an obvious blank section above.

Bolts

Rocket up the corner that marks the far left side of Air Voyage Wall. Mostly a 4th class/low 5th scramble. Eats gear if you put it in, but make sure you save some for the little bit of legitimate climbing at mid height and near the top. Ends at rap rings (traverse a couple of meters to the left after the second steep section), not at rusted pins with webbing. 

This would be a great first trad lead as it protects exceptionally easily. 



The low angle corner at the left end of Air Voyage Wall.

Cams 0.1-3, alpine draws. Rap rings.

What an incredible line! 4 stars!! 
  
 Start on a hard boulder problem which either goes out right to jugs, a small crimp with a heel hook or directly up to a bad finger lock. Pull yourself up and get onto increasingly good holds.  
  
 Soon you reach a good midway rest where you can shake out. Take advantage as you may get pumped in the second section.  
  
 A slab works up the side until you must traverse back onto the face on a crescent  shaped crimp to a big reach OR to bad side pulls. Once you get this, don't fall as you negotiate either a mantle or a hard slab. Lots of variations but a incredible route. Originally graded 11c, I gave it 11+ as the enduro nature makes it a bit harder.

Basically the left edge of the Air Voyage wall. This is the wall with a big boulder that is about 4m away from the climbs and requires scrambling to get to the top climbs
10 bolts to anchor

Excellent route for the grade with great protection.

If you were to walk out of the outhouse, it would be several metres to your left.
Gear to 3".

This is an excellent crack climb, albeit quite short. Start up the hand sized crack system, follow it as it traverses right, then fire up to the anchor. There is a wide bit at the start of the traverse and a fingery bit right after it, but a good hand jam is almost always within reach and there are often good ledges for your feet. This thing is slightly overhung and pumpy, and thankfully there are awesome jugs at the top from which you can clip the anchor.

Look for an obvious rightward traversing crack near the right hand side of the wall.
Cams BD 0.3 to 3. Doubles in hand sizes useful. There is a two bolt anchor at the top.

Climb up past a crack then make a few moves on good quartzite finger edge with poor feel.

Bolted

A mostly bolt protected link up climbing the Extra Dry/Heathens weakness into the crux of DEW Line. 

Start on Extra Dry, the right-most crack on Air Voyage Wall. Long draw the anchors and step left into the much thinner broken crack system of Where Heathens Rage. Use the few spots where you can fit your fingers in the weakness (mostly holds, not finger-locks) to pass a bolt and a Lost Arrow pin, reaching a second bolt where the crack disappears. Clip the bolt and boulder hard right to the heavily chalked hold at the base of the DEW Line crux. Finish out on DEW Line (2 more bolts). 

Skip the pin that's roughly level with the Extra Dry anchors. Extra Dry takes cams @0.4-2, Manhattan doesn't really warrant gear, but you could fit in a 0.2 or 0.3 down low if you skip the Extra Dry anchors. 



Locate Extra Dry, the rightmost crack on Air Voyage Wall. Head straight up and arch right after the second bolt to the arete.

Cams 0.4-2, 5+ QDs, 1+ alpine, 2 bolt anchor with biners.

climbs.name: Mr. Rogers Smokes a Fat One

content.description:
Starts with a blocky crack, then continues straight up.

Crux is some crimps before the last bolt. A small traverse left on good holds takes you to the anchor.

Awesome endurance route; super pumpy. Harder if you can't hand jam.

Left side of the wall. Scramble up through an alcove to a platform.
11 bolts

A memorable climb, the pump builds and builds but good rests are available and much obliged.  Start near the base of the ramp, just next to the yellow block.  Start up moderate ground linking a combination of face holds and good jams/locks.  Some strenuous moves deposits you beneath the mini roof where good gear and a comfortable stance helps you prepare for the crux.  Surmount the roof and get established in the thin crack above; move quick (fixed wire).  Continue up and left past a bolt and a perfunctory pin to the anchors of Air Voyage (P1).   
 Variations and extensions are legion, described above is the most common practice.

Middle Air Voyage wall, begins left of the little shrubbery filled crack and next to a yellow block.
Wires and cams to 2".  This peach eats the wires.

This mega line is one of the best single pitches of the grade anywhere. 

You might just fall off a jug if you don’t manage your pump carefully. There are many cruxes and every shake is on your arms.

Climb Scared Peaches P1 past the roof, then continue straight up towards a line of bolts instead of branching left. Follow the bolts up to a wickedly steep, left leaning LF corner. Save some tips to big finger sized gear for the upper corner unless you want to take the ride of the century.



Start on Scared Peaches P1, the second crack from the right side of Air Voyage wall. Scramble up into the gulley at the base of the wall to get to the start.


1x 0 or blue alien, doubles from tips to #0.75, 2x #2. Extra tips to 0.5.

Yellow to Red DMM offset nuts.

Quickdraws for every piece and a sling or two for the roof.

4 bolts in upper section.

70m rope and lower twice using Scared Peaches P1 anchor, or 80m rope to the ground. Recommend lowering twice if cleaning gear when lowering.

The upper anchor has tat and quicklinks. Please bring some chain and steel biners and remove the tat.

I am all out of hardware or I would have done it already!

Mostly sport climbing starting on the trad climb of scared peaches climbing into Jason Lives. Very thin edging to the last crux of Jason.

Start as for Peaches
Bolts, maybe a cam or two for the thin start

Climb "Extra Dry" and have a chill at the anchor. Cruise through "Heathen" and have a chill at the anchor. Time for Geezas.

The 15 m extension starts with a mini boulder characteristic of Air Voyage Wall. As soon as you pull it, you'll likely want to plug in a piece, the lone bolt is still not so close. Big moves get you to a clipping stance and a quick shake before another boulder. Pretty much bucket slamming after that. On small buckets, and it's really steep. You might want to put in another piece. 

Thank the carabiner gods that put carabiners on the chains. And also the bolt gods that put in the bolt. 

DG says it's 12d if you touch the arete. 



Right-most crack on Air Voyage Wall. Think of it as Extra Dry pitch 3. 

Extra Dry; hand to loose fingers gear: Heathen; 3 bolts, 1 pin, loose fingers to tips gear; Geezas; 1 bolt, a pair at 0.2.

Start by climbing "Extra Dry"  - the right-most crack system at Air Voyage Wall. Put a long runner on one of the anchor bolts and step left into the thin crack/seam. Climb past a bolt and a pin to reach a third bolt where the broken crack/seam pinches shut (sustained). 

Traverse hard left to another crack/seam using good finger holds, swinging your feet onto a big rail and impressing your spectators who don't know how easy this traverse is. Continue up for several meters of pumpy climbing to an okay rest at a reasonable horizontal hold. 

Here you have two options - continue straight up pulling through the overhang to reach the bolt, or, traversing right and skirting the overhang on a left leaning crack (~same difficulty). Clip the bolt and boulder over the small roof (crux) to an extremely airy rest. Plug some gear and finish out through the thin crack to the chains.

Gear beta in the comments-



Start in the furthest right crack system at Air Voyage wall ("Extra Dry") and connect the dots to the bolt you can see ~4 m left of the arete just below the roof (~even with the DEW Line chains). 

Extra Dry - BD 0.5-2 + runners, Heathens' - 3 bolts, 1 pin, cams 0.2-0.5, nuts. Fixed anchor w biners
A daunting wall of overhanging rock with some inspiring lines.   With trad lines in the upper 12s and classic sport routes in the 11s this is a great place if you are climbing the grade.
